Description: Head of M. Antonius right, bearded; behind, lituus; before, inscription. Border of dots. (obverse)
Laureate head of Julius Caesar right; behind, jug; before, inscription. Border of dots. (reverse)
State: Associated with: Roman Republic Ancient Greece and Rome: Roman Republic
Production place: Minted in: Gaul (Cisalpine and Transalpine Gaul)
Curator's comments: The head of Antony on his coins attributed to Gaul is still recognizable, but rendered in a much cruder style.
Bibliographic references: RR2 / Coins of the Roman Republic in the British Museum, vol. 2. Coinages of Rome (continued), Roman Campania, Italy, the social war, and the provinces. (54, p.397)
Walker & Higgs 2001 / Cleopatra of Egypt: from History to Myth (240)
PCR / Principal coins of the Romans: Volume I: The Republic c. 290 - 31 BC; Volume II: The Principate 31 BC - AD 296; Volume III: The Dominate AD 294 - 498. (259)
Ghey, Leins & Crawford 2010 / A catalogue of the Roman Republican Coins in the British Museum, with descriptions and chronology based on M.H. Crawford, Roman Republican Coinage (1974) (488.1.2)
Associated names: Named in inscription & portrayed: Mark Antony
Named in inscription & portrayed: Julius Caesar
